channel.title: Sibling house
channel.description: We're a network of homes where siblings can live together, as a family, while in foster care

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: seattlegivecamp
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Programs
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Sibling House is dedicated not only to providing a haven for children, but also to raising the public awareness of, and to help contribute to the education of, the general populace about foster care and the entire foster care system. This includes identifying, and providing support, through our Mentoring and Outreach Program to other foster homes that provide care to siblings in foster care.

The Mentoring and Outreach Program

Typically, 40% of foster parents quit the program during the first year. The primary reasons are the financial burden and frustration of working with the system. Combining the experience of Sibling House, and veteran foster parents from the Sibling House Network, we can provide guidance and material support to foster parents willing to take sibling groups.

Project Sheltering Tree

Studies show that nearly 50% of children in foster care fail to graduate from high school. Project Sheltering Tree provides academic advocacy, and tutoring, for foster children in the Sibling House Network. Tutors work in partnership with homeroom and special education teachers and foster parents, to advocate for the needs of the child and to complement the programs already in place. Since it’s inception, Project Sheltering Tree has provided 485 hours of tutoring to 29 kids.

Enrichment Program

There’s more to life than food and shelter. Donations to Sibling House make it possible to offer activities that improve foster kids lives. Swimming lessons, little league, the theater, museums, Woodland Park Zoo, Safeco Field, and more, all help to enrich the lives of these less fortunate children.

Outdoor Experience Program

This program focuses on offering the children and families of The Sibling House Network the opportunity to participate in the many natural resources and experiences of the Pacific Northwest. For example, a Sibling House Network camping weekend to Camano Island State Park.
  This is just a snapshot of what Sibling House offers. Please contact us for more information. Sibling House is a 501c3 organization and listed on the Washington State Charitable Solicitations Register.

item.title: Coldwell Bank
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We give back to Sibling House with our Community Partnerships

Coldwell Banker Bain Sales Associate Blair Mus has created a unique relationship with the Sibling House organization. Each time a Sibling House organization member, friend or relative of a member buys or sells a home with Blair Mus, Blair and Coldwell Banker Bain will donate an amount equal to 10 percent of his commission to Sibling House. Coldwell Banker Bain established its Community Partnership program as a way for the company and its agents to give back to the organizations that are committed to the welfare of our communities. Since the program was founded, Coldwell Banker Bain agents have donated more than $1.36 million to organizations in the Puget Sound area. Recognized by SEATTLE MAGAZINE as a top Realtor in the Puget Sound Region, Blair is the leading sales associate of the 90 agents at Coldwell Banker Bain’s Kirkland branch. By zealously representing the interests of his clients throughout the greater Seattle area, the North end and the Eastside, Blair has been in the top 5 in sales production for the last 4 years. For more information on the [Name of Organization] partnership, contact [Non-profit contact name] at (000) 000-0000.

item.title: Group Architect
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Grouparchitect announced in April 2009 a unique support partnership with Sibling House, a non-profit organization dedicated to keeping siblings together while in foster care. The partnership supports the housing need assessments, construction coordination, and permitting assistance for the network of foster care families that make up Sibling House. At this time, there are 86 families with 110 caregivers and over 260 children in this network. Sibling House is a local organization with far-reaching support all over Washington State and beyond. Their mission to care for others in their time and need has reached out to hundreds of children since the organization's founding in 1997. Learn more about how you can help at www.siblinghouse.org.

item.title: Mentoring and Outreach
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Sibling House is dedicated not only to providing a haven for children, but also to raising the public awareness of, and to help contribute to the education of, the general public about foster care and the entire foster care system. This includes identifying, and providing support, through our Mentoring and Outreach Program to other foster homes that provide care to siblings in foster care, essentially, more "Sibling House(s)". Typically, 40% of foster parents quit the program during the first year. The primary reasons are the financial burden, and frustration at working with the system. Sibling House can assist in these areas as well as many others. Providing food, clothing, furnishings, access to enrichment programs, and even passing on vehicles that have been donated to Sibling House can help to lessen the financial impact of providing care to foster children.

The combined experience of the founders of Sibling House, and veteran foster parents from the Sibling House Network, can assist both new foster parents, as well as foster parents willing to take sibling groups. By sharing our knowledge, perseverance, and access to other resources, we can help to alleviate many of the fears, frustrations, and feelings of "no one knows what I'm going through". Often knowing that there is a source that can appreciate the challenges of foster care, and offer concrete, working, solutions to those challenges, will help foster families to thrive and grow. The end result is more families remain in the system and available to children in foster care.

If you need more information, please contact us.

item.title: Project Sheltering Tree
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Studies show that nearly 50% of children in foster care fail to graduate from high school. With all of the trauma and uncertainty these children have faced, it is no surprise that there is little incentive for them to focus on their education. Without a high school degree, there is little hope that they will become self-sustaining adults. Inspired by this realization, Project Sheltering Tree was born. Project Sheltering Tree provides academic advocacy for foster children in the Sibling House Network. Tutoring for grades K through 12 is offered to children that are struggling to reach grade level standards in all subjects. Tutors work in partnership with homeroom and special education teachers and foster parents to advocate for the needs of the child to compliment the programs already in place. In addition to support for the children, Project Sheltering Tree provides advocacy for care givers in the form of guidance, support, and mentoring. PST works on educating foster parents on specialized needs in the confusing world of Individualized Education Plans, 504 Plans, and modified expectations for the child. Project Sheltering Tree started in 2006 on a trial basis with one child receiving tutoring twice a month. This student was below grade level at the beginning of the school year. Through tutoring and teacher accommodations, he was brought up to grade level by the end of the school year. Since then we have been able to supply tutoring services to more than 12 foster children in our network and countless others have recieved school supplies and books. Additionally, we have started a collection of curriculum with resources primarily geared towards reading, writing and math. We will continue to build our collection to support grades K-12 with appropriate material to assist tutors, students, and care givers in making the gains necessary to bridge the academic gaps and ultimately graduate from high school. This is just the beginning of what Project Sheltering Tree envisions for foster children and their futures. As funding increases, we are able to advocate for more children in need. The exponential growth is within our reach. You can help make a difference in the future of foster children with a donation to Project Sheltering Tree. If you would like to make a donation to Project Sheltering Tree, please click on the Donate Now link and type PST in the questions/comments section.

If you need more information, please contact us.

item.title: Fund Raiser Auction 2015
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Wow! What a wonderful evening we all had at the 13th Annual Sibling House Auction on Saturday! Held at The Washington Athletic Club in downtown Seattle, the place was filled with generosity. The WAC staff made us and our guests feel important. Our planning and production team are incredible. The evening came off without a hitch. Lady Yum of Kirkland, supplied all the Dessert Dash desserts and they were a gift to our eyes and our taste buds! Pat & Chris Cashman, our MC/Auctioneers, kept the night hopping and really entertained our guests. And our guests opened their hearts and their wallets and made the event a huge success. We are humbled by the support and faith that so may generous people donated to help Sibling House continue our mission of providing support to a network of homes where siblings can stay together, as a family, while in foster care. It Takes a Village....and we are truly blessed to have so many people in ours!

item.title: Thank you
item.dc:creator: John
item.content:encoded:
You Made A Difference Today!

Thank you for your support of SiblingHouse It is through the support of our "Army of Angels" that we are able to make a difference in these kid's lives. We are grateful for your help!

item.title: Sibling House Auction RSVP
item.dc:creator: seattlegivecamp
item.content:encoded:
What: Annual Sibling House Auction

When: March 19th, 2016. Doors open at 6 PM

Where: The Washington Athletic Club 1325 Sixth Avenue Seattle WA 98101

Parking included at the WAC parking garage - 1/2 block North on Sixth Avenue.

This 14th annual Sibling House fundraising event is not just your typical auction. We make it a lot more fun! Three hours of events that include a Silent Auction, 20 tickets to a private dinner  prepared by Chef Harry Mills at Purple Café and Wine Bar, Wine Pull, Best Of Live Raffle, Share the Pot Raffle, Live Auction, Fund The Needs, a Dessert Dash, and more! All this plus drinks, appetizers, and a plated dinner at a beautiful venue!

On top of that, TV and Radio personality Pat Cashman from 'Almost Live' and 'the 206', along with our own Amy Hall, will be our MC/Auctioneers. Hang on for a very entertaining evening!

You don't want to miss this special event that helps a very worthy cause.

Go to Sibling House Auction  to see what we have to auction, reserve your seat, choose your menu entrée, and purchase your tickets.

If you can't be with us, kindly RSVP via email to lgaskill@siblinghouse.org

  Thanks!   Hope to see you there!

Want to help to support Sibling House but can't join us that evening? Please consider making a donation by clicking on the Donate button in the upper right corner of any Sibling House page. Much appreciated!

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Sibling House is a network of homes where siblings in foster care can stay together in a loving environment while separated from their birth parents. Within this environment the values of family unity are practiced. Life skills such as working together towards a common benefit, playing together, confronting and overcoming challenges, helping and relying on each other are all emphasized. Interactive traditional educational skills such as reading, writing, math, and science encourage children to learn. Cause and effect choices, discipline, responsibility and respect towards self and others, personal health and hygiene, are all a part of the daily routine. These lessons, and more, are a part of a consistent message of unity and unconditional love and are what Sibling House is about. It has already been demonstrated at Sibling House that this consistency allows foster children to thrive and grow. Based in Kirkland, Washington, with a second distribution site in Renton, Washington, Sibling House was co-founded in 1997 by Michael & Lynne Gaskill, and is a Washington non-profit organization registered with the I. R. S. as a 501c 3 charity. Donations to Sibling House can usually be claimed as a tax exempt donation on income tax returns. Sibling House is dedicated not only to providing a haven for siblings to stay together, but also to raising the public awareness of, and to help contribute to the education of, the general populace about foster care and the entire foster care industry. This includes identifying, and providing support, through our programs to other foster homes that provide care to siblings in foster care, essentially, more "Sibling House(s)". As any parent knows, raising children also is an expensive challenge. According to a recent U.S. Dept. of Agriculture study, it costs more than $1147 a month to raise a child to age 18. Foster parent support payments from the state supply less than 50% of this amount. Medical coverage from Medicare and utilizing local resources for therapy and enrichment programs also help to make up the difference, but it still falls short of what's needed. At Sibling House, 84% of every dollar goes to providing care for the children. 8% goes to administrative expenses. 8% goes to fundraising. It is through the efforts of volunteers, and donations from businesses and members of the community that we attempt to provide for these children. Unconditional love is found in abundance at Sibling House. Food, clothing, and other programs work to provide additional learning and growth opportunities that help to enrich the lives of children at Sibling House and the Sibling House Network. Sibling House provides many resources to the siblings we provide care for including The Enrichment Program, The Mentoring and Outreach Program, The Outdoor Experience Program. We are foster child advocates, offer public education programs, and are a foster parent recruitment and resource. We were named "Charity of the Month" by KMPS Radio in September, 2004. Sibling House Executive Director and Co-Founders, Michael & Lynne Gaskill, have 24 years as licensed foster care providers, were 1999 and 2000 year nominees for the Jefferson Award, have 16 years Public Health Service, and are Fosterparentscope certified. Sibling House is governed by a Board of Directors, operating under bylaws and articles of incorporation filed with the Secretary of State for the State of Washington, and listed in the Charitable Solicitations Register in Washington State.

Coldwell Banker Bain Sales Associate Blair Mus has created a unique relationship with the Sibling House organization. Each time a Sibling House organization member, friend or relative of a member buys or sells a home with Blair Mus, Blair and Coldwell Banker Bain will donate an amount equal to 10 percent of his commission to Sibling House. Since the program was founded, Coldwell Banker Bain agents have donated more than $1.36 million to organizations in the Puget Sound area.

Grouparchitect announced in April 2009 a unique support partnership with Sibling House, a non-profit organization dedicated to keeping siblings together while in foster care. The partnership supports the housing need assessments, construction coordination, and permitting assistance for the foster care families that make up The Sibling House Network.

item.title: News
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Happy New Year from Sibling House!

Once again, the past 12 months have been another year of growth for Sibling House and it’s time to report back to you on what we have accomplished this past year through the generosity of our donors.

We now have 153 homes in the Sibling House Network! That’s 33 more homes than this time last year. A 26% increase. Clearly, the need for help is there.

Since our founding in 1997, we have been able to help 520 children and their caregivers by providing various forms and amounts of support.  Some of these homes needed help
just once, many on an ongoing basis.

For many people, 2011 was a year of tight budgets, and uncertain futures. The same was true for Sibling House. Additionally, there was a significant increase in the number of children that entered into the foster care system, most of them siblings.  And yet, we found 2011 to be a year of continued progress in our mission of keeping siblings together, as a family, while in foster care.

In spite of the tight economic times, we are inspired by the continued generosity of donors and their awareness that the welfare of foster children is still a priority.

It is through that inspiration that Sibling House continues to move forward.

Some examples of the support that your donations have enabled us to provide to The Sibling House Network are shown on our Programs pages. We would not have been able to provide these programs without the generous support from the “army of angels” that makes Sibling House successful.

Thank You from the bottom of our hearts.
You are stars in our sky!

May 2012 be a fulfilling and prosperous year for you in all the ways that you deserve!

 Sincerely,

Michael & Lynne Gaskill and all the homes in The Sibling House Network!

item.title: Mission Statement
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Sibling House, a network of homes where siblings can stay together, as a family, while in foster care.

This includes identifying, and providing support, through our Mentoring and Outreach, Project Sheltering Tree, Enrichment, and Outdoor Experience Programs, to other foster homes that are willing to provide care to siblings in foster care, essentially, more "Sibling House(s)". It is through the efforts of volunteers, corporate sponsors, strategic alliances with business and the community, and generous benefactors from all walks of life, that Sibling House works to reach the goals of the founders. In the true essence of "giving back to the community" we all share the ideals of Sibling House. We at Sibling House invite you to join us in making a difference, today...and tomorrow. It Takes a Village......

item.title: Inspiration
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
As an old man walked down a beach at dawn he saw ahead of him what he thought to be a dancer. The old man gazed in wonder as a young man ran across the sand again and again rhythmically bending down to pick up a starfish and throw it into the sea. The old man approached him and asked why he spent so much energy doing what seemed like a waste of time. The young man explained that the stranded starfish would die if left in the morning sun. "There must be thousands of miles of beach and millions of starfish. What makes you think you make a difference?" The young man looked down at the small starfish in his hand and, as he threw it safely back into the sea, said "It makes a difference to this one!"

- Author Unknown -

item.title: Events for Family
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Camping on Camano Island 2015

Hi everyone, It's time to get ready for the annual camping trip to Camano Island State Park. We're planning on camping there from Friday evening, June 12th through Sunday late morning or early afternoon, June 14th. Bring your shelter, sleeping bags, food and cooking equipment. Sibling House will also bring additional food to contribute to the Saturday evening BBQ and for extra goodies and left at home items. We'll have the travel trailer for hot water and the occasional cup of coffee. Plan on having food and everything available for the group you are bringing and we'll all look out for each other. Remember that Washington State Parks waive overnight fees for foster families. Be sure to bring a copy of your current license. We'll plan on playing at the beach on Saturday, and smores for Saturday night. Rain or shine. We'll be there. If you get lost or can't find the group, call my cell at 425-681-9288 and we'll guide you in. Generally, we camp in the lower loop but you never know! Always a lot of fun and camaraderie. Email us at lgaskill@siblinghouse.org. if you plan on joining us. 4th of July Parade & BBQ 2015 We are in the planning stages of our annual 4th of July Parade and BBQ. This will take place in Kirkland on the 4th beginning around 10:30 or 11:00. Kids and caregivers will accompany the Sibling House Van as we wind through downtown Kirkland celebrating this American tradition. This year’s theme is “Celebrating Our Diversity” which really defines the foster community! If you have participated in the past and still have your Sibling House T-Shirt, please bring that to wear. We have a very limited amount of extra T-Shirts that we will bring. Or if you have a white t-shirt, feel free to decorate it with your own 4th of July theme.  Bring sunscreen and snacks as we normally don’t get to eat back at our place earlier than 1:30 or so. We’ll bring bottled water. Afterwards, join us at Sibling House at 10454 NE 112th St. Kirkland, 98033 for a huge BBQ where we will have a waterworks party and lots of good food and conversation with other foster families. The BBQ is from 1-5 PM. Clothing, bicycles, toys, books, and other useful items will be displayed and available to take home with you. An official notice went out to the Sibling House Network recently via email providing details. Hope to have you join us! Please RSVP for food planning. Thanks for all you do for the kids! Michael & Lynne

Plus a $400 gift card to Canlis Restaurant."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_1248" align="alignleft" width="210" caption="The Canlis Restaurant."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_1253" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="4 tickets to the taping of 'the 206' with Pat & Chris Cashman, plus tickets for 2 adults and 2 youths on the Emerald City Trolley Tour, tickets to The Seattle Aquarium, plus two 2.5 hour passes to Adventura Play Park in Redmond."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_1265" align="alignleft" width="220" caption="Adventura Play Park"][/caption]

item.title: Get Involved
item.dc:creator: seattlegivecamp
item.content:encoded:
Check out more information on how to get involved with us.
  • Learn about our partners
  • Give to Sibling House
  • Join the Auction Fundraiser

item.title: Our Mission
item.dc:creator: seattlegivecamp
item.content:encoded:
Sibling House is a network of homes where siblings in foster care can stay together in a loving environment while separated from their birth parents.
This includes identifying, and providing support, through our Mentoring and Outreach, Project Sheltering Tree, Enrichment, and Outdoor Experience Programs, to other foster homes that are willing to provide care to siblings in foster care, essentially, more "Sibling House(s)". It is through the efforts of volunteers, corporate sponsors, strategic alliances with business and the community, and generous benefactors from all walks of life, that Sibling House works to reach the goals of the founders. In the true essence of "giving back to the community" we all share the ideals of Sibling House. We at Sibling House invite you to join us in making a difference, today...and tomorrow. It takes a village......

item.title: Testimonials
item.dc:creator: seattlegivecamp
item.content:encoded:
Thank you so much for the support you have given our family. Our 3 foster girls have been bused by your generosity and our whole family appreciates it. From clothing, the dresser, Dakota’s Brand New Bike and the tickets to the Ugly Duckling play have been so wonderful. The work you do helps us to be better at the work we do as parents. Thank you from all of us! Blessings, The Anderson Family
Thank you for the fun party, books and gifts for the kids. They really look forward to the party. It’s the highlight of the season! Thank you for all your work on behalf of foster siblings! All the best, Darryl and Donette
The sibling house mass e-mailings are productive in placing kids!!! I was able to get  3 teen boys placed and one transgendered child here in my area for Snohomish county. The transgendered kiddo is on cloud nine w/ the placement option and the LONG wait for suitable placement is over. Lewis County still has TONS of homes open for foster to adopt 0-6. I know a few that would interested in siblings.The relationship formed through the placement e-mailings has also helped other countries place kids and promote some 'repairing' of working relationships between a couple different counties. So, answer to the question if SH is helping Kids? YOU BET! In the last month, just in my little word down here, we’ve been able to place 4 kids that nobody thought the would be able to place, one of which has been waiting in limbo for several months because suitable placement could not be found. Now that teen is starting HS completion, beauty college, looking at design school, and is placed in a home where his choices and dreams will be supported. Thanks again for all you do!!!
Dear sibling house, Thank you for hosting the party. It was very fun! My favorite parts of the event is when you can go shopping for Usborne books and when you get stockings fall of toys (And I also like the pizza) Thank you again! Sincerely, Cecelia

item.title: Give to Sibling House
item.dc:creator: seattlegivecamp
item.content:encoded:
Did you know 40% of foster parents quit the program during the first year? The primary reasons are the financial burden, and frustration at working with the system. Sibling House helps support foster parents by providing food, clothing, furnishings, access to enrichment programs, and even passing on vehicles that have been donated to Sibling House. This helps to lessen the financial impact of providing care to foster children, and enriches the foster children's lives. There are many ways that you can enable us to help these families.

In Kind Donations

We accept gently used men’s, women’s, children’s clothing along with small household items. Contact us for more details.

Amazon Smile

Every time you make a purchase at smile.amazon.com,  Amazon donates 0.5% of the price of your eligible AmazonSmile purchases to the charitable organization of your choice. AmazonSmile is the same Amazon you know. Same products, same prices, same service. Support Sibling House by starting your shopping at smile.amazon.com

Amazon Wishlist

Donate through our Amazon Wish List and you can have the items shipped directly to Sibling House.    

PayPal Donate

Your generous donations are appreciated.

item.title: About us
item.dc:creator: seattlegivecamp
item.content:encoded:
Sibling House is a network of homes where siblings in foster care can stay together in a loving environment while separated from their birth parents.

Within this environment the values of family unity are practiced. Life skills such as working together towards a common benefit, playing together, confronting and overcoming challenges, helping and relying on each other are all emphasized. Interactive traditional educational skills such as reading, writing, math, and science encourage children to learn. Cause and effect choices, discipline, responsibility and respect towards self and others, personal health and hygiene, are all a part of the daily routine. These lessons, and more, are a part of a consistent message of unity and unconditional love and are what Sibling House is about. It has already been demonstrated at Sibling House that this consistency allows foster children to thrive and grow. 

Based in Kirkland, Washington, with a second distribution site in Renton, Washington, Sibling House was co-founded in 1997 by Michael & Lynne Gaskill, and is a Washington non-profit organization registered with the I. R. S. as a 501c 3 charity. Donations to Sibling House can usually be claimed as a tax exempt donation on income tax returns.

Sibling House is dedicated not only to providing a haven for siblings to stay together, but also to raising the public awareness of, and to help contribute to the education of, the general populace about foster care and the entire foster care industry. This includes identifying, and providing support, through our programs to other foster homes that provide care to siblings in foster care, essentially, more "Sibling House(s)".

As any parent knows, raising children also is an expensive challenge. According to a recent U.S. Dept. of Agriculture study, it costs more than $1147 a month to raise a child to age 18. Foster parent support payments from the state supply less than 50% of this amount. Medical coverage from Medicare and utilizing local resources for therapy and enrichment programs also help to make up the difference, but it still falls short of what's needed.

At Sibling House, 84% of every dollar goes to providing care for the children. 8% goes to administrative expenses. 8% goes to fundraising. It is through the efforts of volunteers, and donations from businesses and members of the community that we attempt to provide for these children. Unconditional love is found in abundance at Sibling House. Food, clothing, and other programs work to provide additional learning and growth opportunities that help to enrich the lives of children at Sibling House and the Sibling House Network. Sibling House provides many resources to the siblings we provide care for including The Enrichment Program, The Mentoring and Outreach Program, The Outdoor Experience Program. We are foster child advocates, offer public education programs, and are a foster parent recruitment and resource.

We were named "Charity of the Month" by KMPS Radio in September, 2004. Sibling House Executive Director and Co-Founders, Michael & Lynne Gaskill, have 24 years as licensed foster care providers, were 1999 and 2000 year nominees for the Jefferson Award, have 16 years Public Health Service, and are Fosterparentscope certified.

Sibling House is governed by a Board of Directors, operating under bylaws and articles of incorporation filed with the Secretary of State for the State of Washington, and listed in the Charitable Solicitations Register in Washington State.
